docs.abstract: Products that we enjoy continue to create privacy, misinformation and workplace issues. We can do better at getting the industry to do better.

docs.lead_paragraph: It has never felt worse to be a technology consumer. So what can you do about it?

headline.main: Yes, You Can Be an Ethical Tech Consumer. Here’s How.

docs.abstract: Workers at tech companies like Amazon are starting to use the stock grants that they were paid to turn the tables on their employers.
docs.snippet: Workers at tech companies like Amazon are starting to use the stock grants that they were paid to turn the tables on their employers.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley technology firms are known for giving stock to their workers, a form of compensation that often helps employees feel invested in their companies.

headline.main: Tech Workers Got Paid in Company Stock. They Used It to Agitate for Change.
headline.print_headline: Workers Got Stock. Then They Took Action.

headline.main: The Five Most Important Stories of 2018

docs.abstract: The Amazon series based on Michael Connelly’s Los Angeles detective novels returns for a fifth season of unadorned police work.
docs.snippet: The Amazon series based on Michael Connelly’s Los Angeles detective novels returns for a fifth season of unadorned police work.
docs.lead_paragraph: With a dozen or so high-profile television series debuting over the next week — the usual number these days — you could reasonably ask why the fifth season of an old-fashioned cop show deserves attention. Isn’t there a woke comedy or an oddball Netflix import we could be talking about?

headline.main: Review: ‘Bosch’ Is Back, Still on the Straight and Narrow
headline.print_headline: Plain and Simple Make a Pretty Good Team

docs.abstract: Technology publications are asking pointed questions about the online retail company. And Apple had rare, surprising bad news about sales.
docs.snippet: Technology publications are asking pointed questions about the online retail company. And Apple had rare, surprising bad news about sales.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: Jeff Bezos, Please Release Your Dirty Selfies

docs.abstract: Profit-sharing plans for rank-and-file employees are vanishing as corporate America has adopted a new approach toward who reaps a healthy company’s gains.
docs.snippet: Profit-sharing plans for rank-and-file employees are vanishing as corporate America has adopted a new approach toward who reaps a healthy company’s gains.
docs.lead_paragraph: Half a century ago, a typical Sears salesman could walk out of the store at retirement with a nest egg worth well over a million in today’s dollars, feathered with company stock. A warehouse worker hired now at Amazon who stays until retirement would leave with a fraction of that.

headline.main: When Sears Flourished, So Did Workers. At Amazon, It’s More Complicated.
headline.print_headline: In Its Heyday, Sears Spread the Wealth. Companies Today Don’t.

byline.original: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: Many locations will receive investment from Amazon if they aren’t home to its second headquarters — and they will escape expensive incentives, too.
